summary: This is a 2006 Palm Beach Post news article detailing the police investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, resulting in a grand jury indictment for felony solicitation of prostitution. It describes allegations of underage girls being brought to his home for massages and sex, police surveillance and trash collection, and tensions between the Palm Beach Police Chief and the State Attorney over the handling of the case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the investigation, indicted for felony solicitation of prostitution. Allegedly paid to have underage girls brought to his Palm Beach home for massages and sex.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: Wrote a memo urging State Attorney Barry Krischer to disqualify himself from the Epstein prosecution, expressing anger over the handling of the case.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: The prosecutor whose office handled the case, presented it to a grand jury. Criticized by Police Chief Reiter for his office's handling.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who stated his client committed no crimes, cited a passed polygraph test, and claimed the grand jury found allegations unsubstantiated.

persons.name: Mike Edmondson
persons.role: Spokesman for the State Attorney's office
persons.context: Commented on the office's general practice of using grand juries when witness credibility is in question, and noted Epstein had retained multiple attorneys.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.role: Harvard law professor, author, defense attorney
persons.context: Identified as one of five attorneys Epstein retained and a friend of Epstein. Could not be reached for comment.

persons.name: Jane Struder
persons.context: Stated that Epstein's $90,000 donation to the police department for a firearms simulator was returned.

persons.name: Heidi Fleiss
persons.context: A woman who facilitated girls for Epstein reportedly compared herself to Heidi Fleiss, the infamous Hollywood madam.

connections.description: Goldberger is identified as Epstein's defense attorney, speaking on his behalf and denying the allegations.
Dershowitz is identified as one of the attorneys Epstein retained and is described as a friend of Epstein.
Police Chief Reiter wrote a memo suggesting State Attorney Krischer disqualify himself due to dissatisfaction with how the case was being handled.
Epstein's personal assistant allegedly facilitated liaisons by calling to arrange for girls and escorting them upstairs in his home.

connections.person2: A Palm Beach Community College student
connections.description: The student allegedly gave Epstein a massage and later brought him six girls, ages 14-16, for massage and sex-tinged sessions.

events.title: Epstein indictment unsealed
events.description: An indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with one count of felony solicitation of prostitution was unsealed.

events.title: Police investigation begins
events.description: Palm Beach police began investigating Epstein after a 14-year-old girl's relative reported concerns.

events.title: Alleged encounter with 14-year-old
events.description: A 14-year-old girl allegedly went to Epstein's home, gave him a massage in her bra and panties, and was paid $300.

events.title: Reiter memo to Krischer
events.description: Police Chief Michael Reiter wrote a memo to State Attorney Barry Krischer urging him to consider disqualifying himself from the Epstein prosecution.

events.title: Donation returned
events.description: A $90,000 donation Epstein made to the Palm Beach Police Department for a firearms simulator was returned to him.

locations: Epstein's waterfront home on the Intracoastal Waterway, Palm Beach
Manhattan (mentioned as location of Epstein's home)
New Mexico (mentioned as location of Epstein's home)
Virgin Islands (mentioned as location of Epstein's home)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was indicted on one count of felony solicitation of prostitution following a Palm Beach police investigation involving surveillance, trash collection, and statements from five alleged victims.
Police alleged Epstein paid to have underage girls (as young as 14) brought to his home for massages and sometimes sex, facilitated by a personal assistant and a college student.
Police Chief Michael Reiter was so dissatisfied with State Attorney Barry Krischer's handling that he wrote a memo suggesting Krischer disqualify himself from the case.
Epstein's attorney, Jack Goldberger, claimed Epstein passed a polygraph test stating he didn't know the girls were minors and that a search warrant found no corroborating evidence.
Epstein had donated $90,000 to the Palm Beach Police Department shortly before the investigation began; the money was returned on the day the indictment was unsealed.
